pullRequest.body:
This PR proves a very general version of the Cauchy-Davenport theorem, namely a lower bound on the size of the product `s * t` of two finsets in terms of the size of `s` and `t`.
We also provide a different proof for linearly ordered cancellative semigroups.


---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: If this is ready for review, you may have forgotten to add the label

Does the following stronger statement hold: either `s` and `t` are contained in a subgroup of cardinality `< #s + #t - 1`, or ` #s + #t - 1 \le #(s * t)`? If so, and if it follows easily from the proof, it might be worth stating it that way first.

No. You need to take translates into account.

~~Once you take translates into account, it's annoying to get from the current proof because we're arguing that if `g • s = s` then `s` contains the subgroup generated by `g`, hence `orderOf g ≤ |s| ≤ |s * t|`. This doesn't very clearly translate to your new statement. I just tried for an hour to no avail.~~

EDIT: I believe it is straight up wrong. You could take small sets `s` and `t` inside `Fin n → Fin 2` such that `s - s` and `t - t` generate the whole group. Then they're not contained in any small translate of a subgroup and all my current lemma is saying is that `|s * t| ≥ 2`.

Sure, your current lemma is not saying anything near what I'm asking. That's why I'm asking :-) If there's a stronger statement which holds, I'd rather have the stronger statement in mathlib. So the question after correcting with translations is : if `#(s * t) < #s + #t - 1`, does there exist a subgroup `H` of cardinality < `#s + #t - 1` such that `s` is contained in a coset `a H` and `t` is contained in a coset `H b`?
And the answer is no, I believe, because of my example above.
I didn't get the example then. Can you spell out the details?

I've read more of the literature and this turns out to be a delicate question: See Theorem C in https://arxiv.org/abs/math/0508179.

This says that `|s + t| ≤ |s| + |t| - 1` iff there exist`s₀ ⊆ s`, `t₀ ⊆ t` and a subgroup `H` such that, writing `q : G → G / H` the quotient map,
* each are contained in a coset of `H`
* `(s₀, t₀)` is an "elementary pair" (see the paper for the definition, it's pretty long)
* `s \ s₀`, `t \ t₀` are unions of cosets
* `|q s + q t| = |q s| + |q t| - 1`
* There exist unique `a ∈ q s`, `b ∈ q t` such that `a + b ∈ q s₀ + q t₀` (which is a singleton since `s₀`, `t₀` are contained in a coset of `H`)

In particular, your proposed theorem is very likely wrong since it seems stronger than Kemperman's theorem.

:v: YaelDillies can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7143144414/job/19453980716)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7143144414/job/19453980447)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7143144414/job/19453980119)

bors d+
Thanks!

bors d+
Thanks!
You should be able to remove these after merging master.
Please expand docs (both module-level and docstrings of individual theorems) so that they are useful for a reader who doesn't know what is the Cauchy-Davenport theorem.

Since you have many lemmas on this relation, I wouldn't make it private.
Also, can you explain its name in the docstring?

This relation is internal to the proof and really uninteresting. In fact, I need this relation solely because I'm following a very general proof. No other proof uses this relation.

I could inline it at the cost of having to state the lemmas as `have` statements. At the very extreme, it could be a `termination_by` call instead.

The only purpose of having it be separated is for ease of writing and clarity. But it doesn't deserve to be part of the public API.

Re the name: Its name says what it does: It's the relation used in the proof by Devos, with the `Mul` added to disambiguate for `to_additive`.

My problem is that you have non-private lemmas talking about a private def, which can lead to weird situations in other files. Either make all of them private, or all of them non-private. 

Can you add in the docstring that this relation is used in the proof of Cauchy-Davenport by a guy named Devos, to clarify the name?
Ah I see! Be reassured, all lemmas mentioning a `private` declaration in their statement are automatically marked `private` themselves.
... Nevermind, it was the case in Lean 3 but this seems to be gone in Lean 4?!

```suggestion
* The second one works in groups by performing an "e-transform". Replace `s` and `t` by `s ∩ s • g`
```

I purposefully gave the simpler example of an e-transform in an abelian group but I guess that wasn't very clear...

I've now clarified the whole sentence.
are they really both strictly smaller, or rather at least one of them is strictly smaller?
Ha! You're right, I got myself confused here.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: The Cauchy-Davenport theorem
